page.title: 09LANDSCAPE
page.content: Most of the area is flat agricultural land,part of the Vale of York. The Vale is almost completely covered by thick glacial deposits and more recent river alluvium. Underlying these deposits are layers of yellowish-red sandstones which were laid down in desert conditions during the Triassic period,millions of years ago. In a few locations the sandstone stands out above the deposits in the Vale. One of the most notable of these outcrops is Brayton Barff which is visible for miles around. The top of the Barff is covered with a deposit of glacial boulder clay much older than that of the surrounding Vale. From the top of the Barff there is an excellent view to the towers of Selby Abbey and York Minster and to the southern edge of the North Yorkshire Moors and the Wolds.
